1.0 EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990 (CAAA), Section 112(r) Risk Management Program rules, outlined in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Part 68 (40 CFR 68) requires covered facilities that handle, manufacture, use, or store any of the toxic and flammable substances listed in 40 CFR 68.130 above the specified threshold quantities (TQs) in a process to develop and implement a Risk Management Program as issued by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (U.S.EPA).  The goal of Part 68 is to prevent accidental releases of substances that can cause serious harm to the public and the environment from short-term exposures and to mitigate the severity of releases that do occur. In general, Part 68 requires that:

Facilities must develop and implement a Risk Management Program and maintain documentation of the program at the site.  The Risk Management Program must include an analysis of the potential offsite consequences of an accidental release, a five-year accident history, a release prevention program, and an emergency response program.

Facilities must also develop and submit a Risk Management Plan (RMP), which includes registration information, to U.S.EPA no later than June 21, 1999, or the date on which the Facility first has more than a TQ in a process, whichever is later.  The RMP provides a summary of the Risk Management Program.  The RMP will be available to federal, state, and local government agencies.



Covered facilities also must continue to implement the Risk Management Program and update their RMPs periodically or when processes change, as required by the Rule.



The Kendall Power Company, LLC Facility (Facility), located at 1401 County Line Road in Minooka, Illinois (the Facility),[1] is a 1,100 megawatt combined-cycle power generation plant that includes four (4) gas turbines, four (4) heat recovery steam generators (HRSGs), four (4) reheat condensing steam turbines, and one wet-induced-draft cooling tower.  Th

e NAICS code for this facility is 221100.  



Major structures supporting power generation at the Facility include a natural gas fuel system, raw water treatment system, boiler feed water demineralization system, and wastewater collection, conveyance and treatment system. One process water storage pond at the Facility is used to store raw water for use as emergency backup water for Facility cooling, treatment, and maintenance operations.  Additional supporting structures at the Facility include various water tanks, electrical transformers, chemical tanks, and curbed and covered areas for boiler chemical feed systems.  Natural gas is the primary fuel to be used in the power generation process. 



To protect the environment, aqueous ammonia is used at the Facility to reduce oxides of nitrogen (NOx) pollutants which are generated from the combustion of natural gas.  Specifically, ammonia is the reducing agent used in the Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) NOx control systems.  The SCR is a post-combustion gas treatment technique that reduces nitrous oxide (NO) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2) in the turbine exhaust stream to molecular nitrogen (N2) and water (H2O).



The Facility is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for site personnel, the community, contractors, and the environment.  To meet this commitment, systems have been established to help ensure safe operation of the processes of this Facility.  One component of these systems is the Risk Management Program that has been established and implemented to assist in managing the risks involved with the storage and use of aqueous ammonia, the only hazardous substances stored and used at the Facility that is regulated pursuant to 40 CFR 68.



1.1    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response - 40 CFR 68.155(a), 40 CFR 68.155(c) and 40 CFR 68.155(e)



At the Facility, comprehensive accidental release prevention and emergency response programs have been established. It is the Facility's policy to adh

ere to all applicable federal, state, and local rules and regulations.  The Facility is committed to the safety of workers, contractors, the public, as well as to the preservation of the environment.  Additionally, the Facility will implement the measures necessary to prevent foreseeable releases of the substances regulated by 40 CFR 68. The measures include:



Employee training in accidental release prevention and emergency response programs/measures

Establishment of safety programs for Facility operations, design, and maintenance of the regulated process

Establishment of a hazard assessment process



Safety depends upon the manner in which ammonia is managed at the Facility, combined with the safety devices inherent in the design of this Facility.  In the event of an accidental release of the regulated substance, all efforts will be made to minimize and control the release to ensure worker safety and prevent injury to the public or damage to the environment.  The Facility is also committed to working with the local emergency planning committee (LEPC) and local fire department to ensure all emergency notification and response measures are effectively planned and executed.



1.2    Stationary Source and Regulated Substance Handled - 40 CFR 68.155(b)



Kendall Power Plant (KPP) is considered a stationary source, fossil-fueled power generation facility with NAICS Code 221112.  For control of NOx emissions, KPP stores and uses more than a threshold quantity (TQ) of 30% aqueous ammonia (CAS No. 7664-41-7), a regulated toxic substance (40 CFR 68.130, Table 1).  The aqueous ammonia solution is at a nominal 30% by weight concentration and is stored at ambient temperature.   



The process addressed in this RMP is transfer of the aqueous ammonia from the delivery tank truck, storage of aqueous ammonia in the storage tank, and transfer from the storage tank to the SCR and dilution systems. Nominal 30 percent (%) by weight aqueous ammonia is periodically delivered by a 5,

000 to 6,000-gallon tanker truck to a single 15,000-gallon above ground storage tank (AST) and is stored at a maximum pressure of 50 pounds per square inch-gauge (psig).  Aqueous ammonia is delivered to the Facility via tank truck by trained qualified personnel using established standard operating procedures to an unloading station equipped with interconnecting piping connected to the horizontally orientated cylindrical AST.  The AST has a maximum storage capacity of 15,000 gallons (33,570 lbs. of ammonia)and is equipped with secondary containment diking and continuous level monitoring.  



Because the RMP aqueous ammonia TQ limit is 20,000 lbs, Kendall is a Program 2 facility, as applicable to 40 CFR 68.10.  The ammonia solution is considered to be a "common water solution of a toxic substance" which is composed of ammonium hydroxide[2] and water (see Safety Data Sheet (SDS), Aqueous Ammonia - Appendix D, Support Documentation).  In sufficient concentrations, aqueous ammonia is an eye, skin and/or inhalant irritant.



Dynegy Kendall is not in the OSHA PSM program, and does NOT store anhydrous ammonia, nor any ammonia solutions that are greater than 44% by weight.



1.3    The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps  



In the event of an accidental release of the regulated substance, all efforts will be made to minimize and control the release to ensure worker safety, prevent injury to the public, or damage to the environment. KPP procedures ensure all emergency notification and response measures are effectively planned and executed.



Both active and passive mitigation systems have been developed and implemented at the Facility to reduce the potential for adverse impacts to human health and/or the environment. The controls/measures include:

* High- and low-level aqueous ammonia above-ground storage tank (AST) alarms

* AST safety relief valves

* AST inventory control

* AST secondary containment system

* Control ro

om monitoring of liquid ammonia operating systems

* Operator checks, including walk down of ammonia system each shift

* Preventative maintenance program

* Unloading process with integral vapor recovery system

* Manned tanker-truck unloading operation

* Employee training in ammonia system operations

* All materials compatible with 30% liquid ammonia



The Facility's Accidental Release Prevention Program consists of the following:

* Review of Safe Upper and Lower operating conditions

* Process Safety

* Hazard Review

* Standard Operating Procedures

* Employee Training

* Preventive Maintenance Program

* Incident Investigation/Response

* Facility Auditing



All personnel handling ammonia at the Facility are instructed to be familiar with:

* Safety Data Sheet (SDS)

* Evacuation Procedures

* Handling Spills and Leaks

* First Aid and Rescue Procedures

* Proper Use of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)

* Proper Use of Respirators

* Location and Use of Shutoff Valves

* Location of Safety Showers and Eyewash Stations

* Operating Procedures

* Prearranged Procedures for Emergency Medical Care



Additionally, personnel involved with hazardous chemical delivery are instructed to be familar with:

* Unloading Procedure

* Contractor Safety

* Emergency Response Plan

* Hazardous Material Delivery

* Job Safety Analysis (JSA)



The Program 2 Prevention Program of the RMP includes:



MSDS & Inventory:

Technical documentation, including process aqueous ammonia storage and SCR operating procedures have been developed to ensure safe operation of the regulated process as well as all plant operations. The process safety measures and documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, chemical inventories, and equipment design/configuration information and diagrams. SDS are maintained at the Facility to provide chemical specific information. 



Hazard Review:

The Facility has a comprehensive program to help identify and control recognized hazards

associated with the regulated process. Within this program, the aqueous ammonia storage and the liquid ammonia SCR process is systematically examined to recognized hazards and to verify that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards. The hazard review is updated every five (5) years, as required.



Standard Operating Procedures:

Written operating procedures for the aqueous ammonia AST system operations are in place, including system startup, normal operations, system shutdown, and unloading operations, to ensure consistency of operations and reduce the potential for accidents. These procedures are to be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. The procedures are periodically reviewed for accuracy and reliability.



Training:

To complement the written procedures for process operations, a comprehensive step-wise employee training program has been developed for all employees involved in process operations. Training programs are designed for both new and experienced operators. New, inexperienced operators are provided basic training in plant operations. After training for new operators is complete, the new operators are to be teamed with experienced operators to learn process specific duties and tasks. After these new operators demonstrate adequate skills and knowledge of the operating requirements and safe operating practices, they are allowed to work independently. 



Equipment:

Practices and procedures have been developed to ensure process controls, pumps and compressors, pressure relief vessels, piping systems and emergency systems are operating properly. The practices/procedures include the performance of Preventive Maintenance procedures, inspections and tests to ensure proper equipment operation and the performance of preventative maintenance. Inspection and test findings are reported to designated management personnel and corrective measures are implemented, as required, to addr

ess any identified issues in a timely manner. Maintenance personnel receive training on process operations, equipment and systems maintenance procedures, emergency response, and work practice safety.



Work Practice Safety:

Work practices, including entry and exit control, and equipment lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures for the isolation of energy sources when required. Also, hazardous material management procedure, hot work program, and confined space entry programs, are followed to ensure safe working conditions throughout the facility.



Incident Investigation:

All incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in a fire or explosion, release to the environment, property damage (major), or personal injury are promptly investigated to determine the cause of the incident, evaluate response measures, and prevent future recurrence.  The results of any incident investigation are provided to management personnel for review and implementation, as determined. All actions taken in response to the investigation findings/recommendation are tracked until completion.



Compliance Audits:

The Facility audits the Risk Management Plan every 3 years to ensure adequate implementation of the programs. Audit findings and recommendations are to be provided to management personnel for review and implementation of corrective measures, as required. Any corrective measures to be implemented will be tracked by Facility personnel until completion.



Regulated toxic chemical specific prevention measures are also in place to help ensure proper use and safe management of aqueous ammonia and its associated processes. These measures will assist in preventing potential accidents caused by human error and/or equipment failures. These measures include containment to help control any release of aqueous ammonia, aqueous ammonia storage system monitoring and ammonia release detection monitoring, and release mitigation measures.

          

1.4    Five-Year Accident History, Summary

- 40 CFR 68.155(d)



There have been no accidents in past 5-years.



1.5       Emergency Response Program



A written Emergency Response Plan has been established and implemented at the Facility.  As a Program 2 facility, Kendall has coordinated response procedures with the Kendall County LEPC and the following Local Fire Departments:

Kendall County Fire Department

Troy Township Fire Department

Morris Fire Protection and Ambulance



This coordination effort includes providing the fire departments with site diagrams and hazardous material information.  Kendall meets with fire department personnel periodically to discuss Facility operations and processes, as well as the location of control room and chemical storage areas.    Table 1 contains the latest emergency phone numbers.



1.6       Planned Changes to Improve Safety 40 CFR 68.155(f)



At the time of the writing of this RMP, no planned changes to the safety program are in progress.
